comment.author: 83325903@N00
comment._content:
It's a beautifully shot portrait with excellent subject background separation. That separation suggests an open aperature and therefore a fast shutter speed - so the dog's leg couldn't have moved.
I think the 'ghost' is the original position of the dog's tail and maybe this was too 'between it's legs' for the owner. Seem's a bit bizarre to edit it but maybe this was a 2nd version and the owner ended up going for the original print as the edit was too obvious. 
Also, I think it is an Irish wolfhound.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/83325903@N00] Nice analysis of the shot, I have to admit that I would not have seen what you see in the technical details so thank you.  It is a very nice shot and study of the handler and dog.  It is indeed an Irish Wolfhound which has been the traditional mascot of the IG's!  I didn't realise that they were posted to Waterford and always assumed that, as a Guards Regiment, they were posted in Britain.  You live and learn.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: You've mapped this at the old Artillery barracks, I think it is more likely the old Parade Ground at the Infantry barracks (since built on, also, too).

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Wikipedia has a history of the Regiment. They were formed in 1900, posted in England until WW1 and deployed to France a week after the War started. In late 1916 they were in the Battle of the Somme, and in 1917 they were at Ypres and Passchendaele.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Rudyard Kipling whose son was a Lieutenant in the Regiment and died in France wrote the definitive and very fine history of the Irish Guards Regiment.  Well worth a read if you can get your hands on it!  Kiplings son was reported missing after a battle and was only located in the past ten years or so.  It broke the family's hearts.

comment.author: 72025404@N08
comment._content: what a great capture! they look so proud. very interesting to see the ghostly limb!

comment.author: 22575440@N07
comment._content: wonderful photo!

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: What a great photo and definitely taken in the infantry barracks.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: The Irish Wolfhound breed is very old; there are suggestions it may have been brought to Ireland as early as 7000 BC, however the breed almost disappeared, but was successfully revived by efforts of the captain of the British Army D E Graham to recreate it. In 1879 he wrote: "It has been ascertained beyond all question that there are few specimens of the breed still left in Ireland and England to be considered Irish wolfhounds, though falling short of the requisite dimensions. This blood is now in my possession." Captain Graham devoted his life to ensuring the survival of the Irish wolfdog. Owing to the small numbers of surviving specimens outcrossing was used in the breeding programme. It is believed that Great Dane, Deerhound and Mastiff dogs all played their part in Graham's creation of the dog we currently know. So the dog in the photo would be an early variant of the Wolfhound we know today.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content:
The dog is very likely Leitrim boy who was presented to the regiment by Lord Powerscourt and was the regimental mascot up until 1917.
 I think the most likely explanation for the presence of the Irish Guards, or at least the band members, in Waterford would have been for the purposes of recruitment, they did a similar tour of Ireland in April 1915.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: You can see the first mascots here. This looks a lot more like Leitrim Boy than the others listed.

Don't want to push my luck here, but we still have no name for the "Little Drummer Boy"...  :D
